title: What music genre requires the most skill? - Quora

response.answer_text: None, in particular. Any musician can develop the capability to make whatever type of music he/she truly desires. I used to think I would never play classical music or read standard notation… guess what? Through determination and work I have achieved just that. And, by the way, “talent” is a myth-- actually a harmful one. As someone who has been creating and performing for 25 years, I have witnessed a lot of harm done by the myth of “talent.” “Talent" is the excuse of the lazy. It is the refuge of minds who have decided that they, or someone else, are magically incapable of something. “I’ll never be as good as X, he’s so talented.” Or, my personal hate-favorite, “Don't quit your day job,” which is what the obstinate and unimaginative say to the person who is actually trying, on their way, to improve. “No one will ever play the guitar like Jimi Hendrix.” “No one will ever dunk like Jordan, because of his rare, magical talent.” Bullsh!t. They've both been surpassed by those willing to put in the work. “Talent” is the false idea that some deity or mysterious force of nature gifted a select few of us with magical abilities, and only us, so the rest of you need not even try. It’s crap. There are some physical limitations/handicaps that can't be overcome, sure. Something like .6% of the population is actually deaf, and only a tiny fraction more than that are physically tone deaf. There are those who have muscular dystrophy or missing limbs, etc— but there are many musicians who have overcome such limitations, so it’s not really non-negotiable (Def Leppard’s drummer is just one example). Tell Spud Webb that a guy under six feet tall can’t dunk, and watch him do it at 5′7″. Muggsy Bogues, though he never dunked in an NBA game, could dunk two-handed at 5′3,” with a vertical leap of 44 inches! There are four factors which determine and contribute to someone's success in any endeavor. Exposure. All the best basketball players grew up in an area where basketball was prized as a sport, in families that encouraged or participated in playing or watching basketball. Many of the best musicians come from “musical families;” not because the mystical “talent” is genetic, no! Musical families are families that promote, encourage, or participate in musical activities. An important reason that so many amazing concert violinists come from China and Japan is that a high number of families there encourage and promote violin as a valued skill.Enthusiasm. Usually due to exposure and the modeling of one’s influences, enthusiasm for a skill leads to exploring the skill and developing it. Without enthusiasm, or passion for something, no one bothers.Determination. This is driven by one’s exposure and enthusiasm. The determination to master a skill is necessary to overcome one’s obstacles, and it is what drives the final factor:Deliberate practice. Practice makes perfect, right? Wrong. There is no perfect. Practice makes permanent. You don’t just practice until you remember/get it right; you practice until you can’t get it wrong. Deliberate practice isn’t just repetition; it’s visualization, specialization, and continued concentration on one’s weaknesses and improving them. A guitarist who is great at chordal playing or scales but not at arpeggios will still practice chords and scales— but he/she will practice harder at arpeggios until the desired progress is made. Everything that is worth doing requires some practice. Everything that one desires to excel at requires deliberate practice.There is no “talent.” There are strength, skill, dexterity, nuance, virtuosity— all of which are gained through work: exposure, enthusiasm, determination, and deliberate practice.  —Alex Krob, an amazing violinist

I grew up in a classic Asian environment, learning piano and cello. My brother played the violin. For 10 years, all I played were classical pieces, so in my mind, I thought that classical pieces were the hardest to compose and to play. Your fingers had to be quick and agile, and you had to play with feeling and technical perfection. Then, I was exposed to jazz. The improvisation, soul, and emotion jazz artists put into their creations is so so impressive and impossible for me to do; it was infinitely harder than playing classical music. Then, I started learning guitar, and creating music with a group of friends in some kind of rag tag band, and I discovered that rock music too requires a lot of skill. Coordinating with others, singing while playing an instrument, and doing all of that well requires so much skill. I know this is a really vague answer that doesn’t really answer your question, but at least to me, all music genres require a great deal of skill. Except for some pop songs where all the sounds are electronically made and the singing is autotuned…
